questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the neonatal finding due to varicella infection in mother during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Features associated with congenital varicella are:

  • Cicatricial skin lesions- Dermatomal distribution
  • Ocular defects like cataracts
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Gastrointestinal abnormalities such as bowel atresia
  • CNS abnormalities like microcephaly, cerebellar hypoplasia
  • IUGR
  • Fetal demise or early death.

questions.text: A newborn infant on examination was found to be having hepatomegaly. Other examination was normal. On detailed history, mother was found to be positive for CMV. On investigation of the child, Anti-IgM CMV was positive. Which of the following is the most common long term sequalae expected in this child?
questions.solution:
• The child has congenital CMV infection. More than 90% babies are asymptomatic.
  • Most common manifestation- Petechial rashes
  • Most common long term sequalae- SNHL
  • Most common lab finding- elevated SGPT/ALT

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Congenital Syphilis:

  • Olympian brow- Bony prominence of the forehead caused by persistent or recurrent periostitis
  • Clavicular or Higoumenakia sign- Unilateral or bilateral thickening of the sternoclavicular third of the clavicle
  • Saber shins- Anterior bowing of the midportion of the tibia
  • Scaphoid scapula- Convexity along the medial border of the scapula
  • Hutchinson teeth- Peg-shaped upper central incisors; they erupt during 6th year of life with abnormal enamel, resulting in a notch along the biting surface
  • Mulberry molars- Abnormal 1st lower molars characterized by small biting surface and excessive number of cusps
  • Saddle nose- Depression of the nasal root, a result of syphilitic rhinitis destroying adjacent bone and cartilage
  • Rhagades- Linear scars that extend in a spoke-like pattern from previous mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, and genitalia
  • Juvenile paresis- Latent meningovascular infection; it is rare and typically occurs during adolescence with behavioral changes, focal seizures, or loss of intellectual function
  • Juvenile tabes- Rare spinal cord involvement and cardiovascular involvement with aortitis
  • Hutchinson triad- Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, and 8th nerve deafness
  • Clutton joint- Unilateral or bilateral painless joint swelling (usually involving knees) from synovitis with sterile synovial fluid; spontaneous remission usually occurs after several weeks
  • Interstitial keratitis- Manifests with intense photophobia and lacrimation, followed within weeks or months by corneal opacification and complete blindness
  • 8th nerve deafness- May be unilateral or bilateral, appears at any age, manifests initially as vertigo and high-tone hearing loss, and progresses to permanent deafness.

questions.text:
A full-term, small for gestational age newborn girl presents with cataracts, petechiae, and a continuous machine-like murmur. Which of the following statements is accurate
I. This infant needs an audiology evaluation because sensorineural hearing loss is a common association.
II. This infant needs a renal ultrasound because she is likely to have renal abnormalities.
III. Treatment of her condition includes 14 days of intravenous penicillin after evaluation of her cerebrospinal fluid.
IV. The infant's condition is likely to have occurred because of a maternal illness during the first trimester.
V. Intravenous antiviral therapy should be initiated and viral cultures should be obtained.
questions.solution:
• This infant has the classic features of congenital rubella syndrome including low birth weight, heart defect (patent ductus arteriosus), and congenital cataracts.
  • Other clinical findings associated with congenital rubella syndrome include purpura, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, retinopathy, glaucoma, pulmonary artery stenosis, meningoencephalitis, thrombocytopenia, and hemolytic anemia.
  • Long-term sequelae of congenital rubella include sensorineural hearing loss, neurodevelopmental abnormalities, growth retardation, endocrine disease (diabetes mellitus, thyroid dysfunction), and hypogammaglobulinemia
  • Maternal infection may or may not be clinically apparent, and infection during the first month is most likely to result in fetal infection with the involvement of multiple organs.
  • No role of antivirals and viral culture in congenital rubella.

choices.text: Hospitalize the patient, obtain HSV surface and vesicle fluid cultures
Obtain CSF for HSV culture and PCR for CNS dissemination
Transmission is more common in second trimester, hence no role of antivirals

questions.text: A 10-day-old infant presents to clinic with a painful, red vesicular rash as below. He is mildly fussy but afebrile, and he has good oral intake. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
• Transmission is more common in perinatal period; hence antivirals have significant role in reducing the active viral infection.
  • CSF analysis is needed to define the extent of disease. HSV PCR of the CSF is the standard for diagnosis.
  • EEG shows PLED (Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharge)

questions.text: A 38-week gestation male infant was precipitously delivered vaginally in the emergency department. Weight and head circumference are less than 5th percentile, and length at 10th percentile. He has hepatosplenomegaly and a petechial rash. Notable laboratory results include platelets of 22,000/mm3 and elevated total and direct bilirubin levels. CT of the head shows bilateral intracranial calcifications with several around the basal ganglia and obstructive hydrocephalus. Ophthalmologic examination reveals chorioretinitis. What is the most likely cause of the patient's findings?
questions.solution:
• The triad of
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Intracranial calcifications
    • Chorioretinitis is a classic presentation for congenital toxoplasmosis
  • Other features include:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Chorio-retinal scars
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Basal ganglia and thalamus damage
  • With cytomegalovirus, the intracranial calcifications would be in a periventricular distribution and the typical rash would be the blueberry muffin rash.
  • Rubella would be expected to also have the purpuric rash along with cataracts and no CT findings.
  • Herpes would have either vesicles or scarring.

choices.text: Children must be isolated from school 5 days after onset of rashes
Pneumonia is the most common complication

questions.text: Which of the following statement about measles in children is false?
questions.solution:
• It is caused by measles virus belonging to paramyxovirus family.
  • It has incubation period of 8-12 days.
  • It is infective 4 days before and 5 days after the onset of the rashes. (hence, children must be isolated from schools 5 days after onset of rash)
  • It starts with prodromal symptoms like cough, coryza and conjunctivitis with fever lasting for 2-3 days.
  • Otitis media is the most common complication and pneumonia is the most common cause of death.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has fever and sore throat since 2 days. On examination there is significant cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The throat examination is shown. Paul Bunnell test is positive. Which of the following condition is not associated with this causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Symptoms + hemorrhagic petechia at the junction of soft and hard palate + positive Paul Bunnell test all are suggestive of Infectious mononucleosis. The causative agent is EBV.

Conditions associated with EBV are:

  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Burkitt's lymphoma
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative disorder
  • HLH syndrome
  • Alice in wonderland syndrome
  • Guillain Barre syndrome

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements about Hand Foot and mouth Disease
i. Humans are the only carriers
ii. Self-resolving in 10-14 days
iii. Lab confirmation is needed for specific treatment
iv. GBS is a known complication
questions.solution:
• Management is supportive, directed toward the relief of pain, lowering of fever, and adequate oral hydration because of the self-limiting nature of HFMD. Admission and intravenous fluids might be required if the child is unable to taking orally, dehydrated, clinically ill, or in case of CNS or cardiac complications.
  • Pain and fever can be managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and acetaminophen but preferably avoided in children with dehydration.
  • Prognosis of HFMD is excellent. Most of the cases recover within few weeks without residual sequelae. Acute illness lasts for 10-14 days. Some may develop serious complications.
  • CNS complications (more common with Enterovirus 71 than Coxsackievirus): Rhombencephalitis (brainstem encephalitis), acute flaccid paralysis, aseptic meningitis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, acute cerebellar ataxia, and benign intracranial hypertension.

Reference: Treatment guideline for HMFD, IAP 2022

choices.text: Immune globulin (IG) plus live attenuated measles vaccine

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy contact with sibling has measles at home. You obtain a complete history and physical examination, which were both unremarkable. What is the appropriate management for the baby?
questions.solution:
• Infants <6 months of age should receive immunoglobulin intramuscular (IGIM) or intravenous (IVIG) within 6 days of exposure.

POST EXPOSURE PROPHYLAXIS IN MEASLES

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy with acute lymphocytic leukemia is currently receiving consolidation chemotherapy. His mother informs you that 9 days ago he was in contact with a child who has now been diagnosed with varicella. Her son has not had varicella in the past. His serologic test results are not available. Of the following, the BEST next step in management is to administer
questions.solution:
• Passive immune-prophylaxis after exposure to varicella is indicated in immunocompromised patients, certain neonates, and pregnant women.
  • Varicella-zoster immune globulin should be given as soon as possible after exposure or up to 10 days after exposure to varicella.
  • For individuals that are nonimmune and exposed but otherwise do not meet criteria for immune-prophylaxis, varicella vaccine can be used if the individual is 12 months of age or older and the vaccine is not contraindicated.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement/s regarding Mumps in children
i. Child is infective 7 days prior to onset of swelling
ii. Parotids are affected, other glands are spared
iii. Mumps epididymo-orchitis is leading cause of infertility in children
iv. Aseptic meningitis is a known complication
questions.solution:
• Mumps is infective 7 days prior to 7 days after onset of swelling.
  • Parotids are most commonly affected, but 10-20% cases have other glands also affected.
  • It is spread by respiratory droplet.
  • Complications:
    • Mumps epididymo-orchitis- more common in adults, cause testicular atrophy
    • Aseptic meningoencephalitis
  • Treatment is supportive

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with a low fever and a modestly itchy skin rash. On physical examination the exanthema consisted of erythematous maculo-papular rash that started on the trunk and the limb roots, with an appearance of goose bumps of the skin. Hyperemic and hypertrophic tonsils and modest hepatomegaly were also present. The day after the exanthema spread to the face and to the latero-cervical and retro-auricular regions. After two days the lesions took on a purpuric color and blanching as shown. The Child is vaccinated for age. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Measles and rubella could be excluded not only for the different appearance but mainly because the child had received specific vaccines.
  • In scarlet fever, the rash begins after one to five days from a feverish onset and starts at the limb roots, then spreads over the entire body surface, typically sparing the perioral region (the Filatov mask). The tongue is white and patinated with red margins, then peels and takes on a raspberry appearance.
  • In our case, the clinical picture was very different due to the onset of the exanthema (although identical in morphology and distribution) at the same time as the onset of fever. Additionally, the fever was low fever, there were good general conditions and an absence of lymphadenomegaly and tonsillar exudate.
  • Typically, the exanthema involves the face with an intense red color. It is mainly on the cheeks with a 'slapped cheek' appearance and spares the perioral area that remains pale.
  • Subsequently, the erythema spreads to the trunk and limbs. Maculo-papular lesions are often itchy and tend to merge into larger patches (megalo-erythema), pale in the center creating a reticulated or cockade appearance.

questions.text: A child comes to see you with a severely sore throat and limited neck movement. No neurological signs or reduced consciousness. Uvula is central. No stridor or drooling. Considering the clinical features, which of these diagnoses would you want to rule out?
questions.solution:
• The limited neck movement should raise suspicion of a retropharyngeal abscess, which can be life threatening if not identified early.
  • Epiglottitis is another important differential to rule out. However, reduced neck movement (or pain on neck movement) is not typical of epiglottitis.
  • Peritonsillar abscess will show shifting of uvula.
  • Croup comes with coryza and fever with stridor.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with sickle cell anemia. He is more susceptible to all the following bacterial infections except
questions.solution:
• All patients with sickle cell anemia are at increased risk of infection and death from bacterial infection, particularly encapsulated organisms such as
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Hemophilus influenzae type b
    • Neisseria meningitidis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature associated with meningococcal sepsis?
questions.solution:
Clinical features associated with Meningococcal sepsis:

  • Feverish child that appears generally unwell
  • Cold hands/feet
  • Leg pain
  • Confusion
  • General signs of shock
  • Non-blanching purpuric rash

choices.text: Pertussis toxin level in oral fluids

questions.text: A 3-year-old child has fever and coughing since last 6 days. His coughing is barking in quality. You suspect pertussis in the child. Which of the following investigation is recommended in the child?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosing pertussis when a cough has a duration of less than two weeks is done with nasopharyngeal aspirate or swab cultures.
  • If the cough has been present for longer than two weeks anti-pertussis toxin IgG serology or Anti-pertussis toxin detection in oral fluids is recommended.
  • Serology and oral fluid testing can give false positives if the patient has been vaccinated within a year.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with low grade fever, headache and nasal congestion. He has a flushed face and has developed lacy reticular rash on the trunk and external surface of his arms and legs. Palms and soles are spared. His mother has been ill with low grade fever and joint stiffness and pain. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Scarlet fever is an upper respiratory tract infection associated with a characteristic rash, which is caused by an infection with pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic toxin)-producing GAS in individuals who do not have antitoxin antibodies.
  • The rash appears within 24-48 hour after onset of symptoms, although it may appear with the first signs of illness. It often begins around the neck and spreads over the trunk and extremities. The rash is a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption producing bright red discoloration of the skin, which blanches on pressure.
  • It is often accentuated in the creases of the elbows, axillae, and groin called as Pastia line. The skin has a goose-pimple appearance and feels rough. The cheeks are often erythematous with pallor around the mouth.
  • After 3-4 days, the rash begins to fade and is followed by desquamation, initially on the face, progressing downward, and often resembling a mild sunburn. Occasionally, sheet-like desquamation may occur around the free margins of the fingernails, the palms, and the soles.
  • The pharynx is red, the tonsils are enlarged and often covered with a white, grayish, or yellow exudate that may be blood-tinged. There may be petechiae or 'doughnut' lesions on the soft palate and posterior pharynx and the uvula may be red and swollen.
  • In addition, the tongue is usually coated and the papillae are swollen. After desquamation, the reddened papillae are prominent, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.
  • Typical scarlet fever is not difficult to diagnose; the milder form with equivocal pharyngeal findings can be confused with viral exanthems, Kawasaki disease, and drug eruptions. Staphylococcal infections are occasionally associated with a scarlatiniform rash.
  • A history of recent exposure to a GAS infection is helpful, as evidenced here by sick mother with joint pain and fever. Identification of GAS in the pharynx confirms the diagnosis.

Mnemonic for Day of appearance of rash in a febrile patient is

  • Very Sick Person Must Take Double Tablets
  • Very - Varicella (day 1)
  • Sick - Scarlet fever (day 2)
  • Person - Pox-small pox (day 3)
  • Must - Measles (day 4)
  • Take - Typhus (day 5)
  • Double - Dengue (day 6)
  • Tablets - Typhoid (day 7)

choices.text: Cephalosporins are the drug of choice
Antitoxin given in all suspected cases

questions.text: Choose the false statement regarding neonatal tetanus
questions.solution:
• It occurs in unimmunized mothers
  • The contamination of umbilical stump during delivery is important cause.
  • Usually presents in 3-12 days of life with feeding difficulties and excessive crying
  • Treatment includes antibiotics- Penicillin G (Drug of choice), Metronidazole/erythromycin (alternative). Human tetanus immunoglobulin must be given in all cases.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presents to the emergency department with a history of fever for 10 days. The child also complains of loose stools, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He has bilateral redness in eyes. The child has a history of a mild episode of COVID-19 before 3 weeks. The child's labs reveal lymphocytopenia, and an elevated C-reactive protein. Which condition would you suspect in this child?
questions.solution:
• Pediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome (PIMS) or Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) is an uncommon complication of COVID-19 that presents in a similar way to Kawasaki disease or toxic shock syndrome.
  • It typically occurs two to six weeks after acute SARS-CoV-2 infection.

WHO CRITERIA FOR DIAGNOSIS OF MISC

  • Age- 0-19 years
  • Clinical features:
    • Fever- ≥ 3 days

PLUS

  • Two of the following:
    1. Rash, conjunctivitis, mucocutaneous inflammation
    2. Hypotension or shock
    3. Cardiac involvement
    4. Coagulopathy
    5. Acute GI symptoms
  • Inflammation markers elevated
    • ESR
    • CRP
    • Procalcitonin
  • Recent evidence of COVID19:
    • Positive PCR
    • Positive antigen test
    • Positive serology

OR

  • Likely COVID19 contact
  • No other microbial cause likely

Reference: https://www.who.int/news-room/commentaries/detail/multisystem-inflammatory-syndrome-in-children-and-adolescents-with-covid-19

questions.text: According to WHO reports, which of the following is the most commonly reported symptoms in COVID19 in children?
questions.solution:
Reported symptoms in COVID19 in children:

  • Fever (56%)
  • Dry cough (54%)
  • Headache (28%)
  • Sore throat (24%)
  • Myalgia (23%)
  • Shortness of breath (13%)
  • Diarrhea (13%)
  • Nausea/vomiting (11%)
  • Coryza (7.2%)
  • Abdominal pain (5.8%)

Fever and dry cough are the most common.

Reference: World Health Organization. Coronavirus. Accessed at: https://www.who.int/health-topics/coronavirus#tab=tab_3)
